titleStmt.title: A machine-readable profile of Manakhah Arabic
titleStmt.author: Gunda Kinzl

sourceDesc.p: This is an original digital text

div.head: Typology (Local)
div.p: Manakhah belongs to the so-called k-dialects which exhibit -k instead of -t in the inflectional suffix of the 1st person sg. perfect, e.g. širib-k ‘I drank’; many archaic features

div.head: General
div.p: Manakhah is a town in the Yemeni governorate of Sanaa and capital of the eponymous district. It lies halfway between Sanaa and Hudaydah in the steep Ḥarāz mountains, at 2322 meters above sea level and is home to several thousand inhabitants.
The main crops of this particularly humid area in Yemen are coffee and qāt, a mild stimulant popular in the region.
The majority of the population in the area are Zaydites, but there is also a shrine visited by Ismaˁīlīs.

The city was once home to a comparatively large and well-established Jewish community which immigrated to Palestine, respectively Israel, in the 19th and 20th centuries. The former Jewish quarter in the al-qarya part of Manakhah today is inhabited by its poorest citizens.

div.head: Research history
div.p: Al-Hamdānī provides early mentions of the dialect area in his Ṣifat Ǧazīrat al-ˁArab. In Western scholarly literature, Rossi 1938, Diem 1973 and Behnstedt 1985 undertake mapping out Northern Yemen, with only Behnstedt explicitly mentioning Manakhah. The most comprehensive study on Manakhah is Werbeck 2001, who objects to Behnstedt’s description of Manakhah as an enclave of t-dialect speakers surrounded by k-dialect speakers. Werbeck 2001 describes the phonology, morphology and selected topics of the syntax and expands on the pronoun, noun and verb. It also provides texts in transcription and German translation. The updated version of the dialect atlas by Behnstedt 2016 includes information provided by Werbeck.
The Jewish dialect may have differed in some ways from the Muslim dialect.

div.head: Dictionaries
div.p: Behnstedt’s and Piamenta’s dictionary of Yemeni Arabic is helpful for all Yemeni dialects. Behnstedt’s atlas of Yemeni dialects offers three volumes of glossary in Arabic-German.
